> If you move the head to a cell that was occupied by a body segment that is not the tail, then after the move, that body segment might still be there or move to a position causing collision.
> 
> Specifically, when you move to a cell that is occupied by a body segment at index K, then after the move, that segment at index K will move to the position of index K-1, but since head moved to its position, it causes the segment to be at a different position, but the key is that after the move, the head is at the new cell, and the body segments are at their new positions.
> 
> In this case, moving to (6,4): before move, (6,4) has index 1.
> 
> After head moves to (6,4), new head at (6,4).
> 
> Then index 1 moves to where index 0 was, (6,5)
> 
> Index 2 moves to where index 1 was, (6,4)
> 
> But (6,4) is now head, so index 2 moving to (6,4) means head and body at same cell, collision.
> 
> Therefore, moving to any cell that is currently occupied by a body segment except the tail will cause collision because after the move, that body segment moves to the new head position or something.
> 
> General rule: if you move to a cell that is not the tail, it is occupied by a body segment that will not move away; it will stay or move to cause collision.
> 
> Only the tail: if you move to the current tail position, after move, the tail moves away, so that cell is only head now.
> 
> In this case, current tail is at (4,5), which is not (6,4), so moving to (6,4) is deadly.
> 
> Similarly, moving to any other body segment except tail is deadly.
> 
> Now, for tail: if I move to (4,5), which is tail, then after move, head at (4,5), and the tail moves away to where the previous segment was, so no collision.

> But in this position, (4,5) is not adjacent to head; head is at (6,5), (4,5) is far.
